title: RCH Core TODOs Master Plan (Hook + WorkerPool + CLI + Tests)
description:
Background
- RCH is a transparent compilation offloading system; the hook must be fast, precise, and fail-open.
- The current codebase has core scaffolding; this plan captures the remaining high-leverage TODOs in a self-contained way.

Scope
- Hook integration (classification → daemon → transfer pipeline → artifacts)
- WorkerPool correctness (counting, status, health recovery)
- rch CLI commands (daemon/workers/status/config/hook) with clear UX
- Comprehensive tests (unit/integration/e2e) + detailed logging

Non-Goals
- New features beyond the above TODOs (e.g., UI, metrics, autoscaling)

Principles
- Fail-open: errors in remote pipeline must allow local execution.
- Precision over recall for classification; correctness over cleverness.
- Observability: log enough to debug without overwhelming normal output.
design: This master epic decomposes three top TODO areas into actionable, dependency-aware tasks, plus a testing epic. The structure allows parallel work while preserving ordering constraints (e.g., CLI tests depend on CLI implementations). Each task includes background, goal, and acceptance to minimize future ambiguity.
acceptance_criteria:
- All child epics are created, linked, and contain granular tasks with dependencies.
- Each task contains enough context to implement without re-reading the long plan document.
- Test tasks explicitly cover unit, integration, and e2e with logging expectations.
notes: If any task is already implemented in HEAD, verify by code inspection + tests, then close with a note referencing evidence.
close_reason: All child epics completed: Hook pipeline, WorkerPool, CLI commands, and Testing/E2E coverage

title: Hook: Remote Execution Pipeline
description:
Purpose
- Complete the hook execution flow end-to-end: classify → select worker → transfer → remote exec → artifact return.
- Enforce fail-open semantics and avoid double-execution.

Key Risks
- Latency regressions in hook path.
- Incorrect deny/allow decisions causing duplicate execution or blocked commands.
- Artifact return correctness for Rust targets.
design: Hook must remain a thin orchestrator; state lives in daemon or transfer pipeline. Prefer small helpers and explicit error handling. Keep stdout semantics aligned with Claude Code hook expectations (empty output = allow).
acceptance_criteria:
- Hook pipeline is fully functional with remote execution and artifact retrieval.
- Fail-open behavior is preserved when any remote stage fails.
- Unit + integration tests exist for the hook pipeline.
notes: If remote pipeline already exists in HEAD, verify all stages (sync/exec/artifacts) and ensure tests cover failure modes.
close_reason: All child tasks complete: TransferPipeline integration, config application, protocol-safe output, and tests

title: Hook: integrate TransferPipeline for remote compilation
description:
Background
- Hook currently classifies commands and selects a worker. It must then orchestrate transfer, remote exec, and artifact return.

Goals
- Wire TransferPipeline into hook flow (sync → exec → artifacts).
- Preserve fail-open if any stage errors.
- Stream remote stdout/stderr to the agent (stderr preferred).

Implementation Notes
- Use `TransferPipeline::new`, `sync_to_remote`, `execute_remote_streaming`, `retrieve_artifacts`.
- Deny local execution after successful remote run to avoid double compile.
- Ensure exit codes propagate meaningfully to hook output.
design: Keep hook code minimal; pipeline complexity stays in transfer module. Ensure minimal allocations and avoid blocking operations in the hook.
acceptance_criteria:
- Remote compilation is executed for classified commands.
- Artifacts returned into local target/.
- Any pipeline failure results in allow/local execution.
- Streaming output visible to agent during remote execution.
notes: Verified in rch/src/hook.rs that TransferPipeline is integrated: execute_remote_compilation builds pipeline, runs sync_to_remote, execute_remote_streaming, and retrieve_artifacts with fail-open handling.
close_reason: Implemented in rch/src/hook.rs (TransferPipeline wired end-to-end)

title: Hook: apply config (threshold, socket path, transfer settings)
description:
Background
- Hook has hardcoded confidence threshold and socket path.

Goals
- Load RchConfig (user + project + env overrides).
- Apply confidence threshold, socket path, and transfer settings.
- Respect global enable/disable flags.

Considerations
- Config loading must be fast; cache if necessary.
- If config parsing fails, fail-open to local execution.
design: Prefer a single `load_config()` call per hook invocation; avoid repeated filesystem reads where possible.
acceptance_criteria:
- Hook uses config values for threshold and socket path.
- Config errors are non-fatal and lead to allow/local execution.
- Unit tests cover env overrides and project config precedence.
notes: Implemented config usage in rch/src/hook.rs: load_config with fail-open on error, check general.enabled, use compilation.confidence_threshold, use general.socket_path for daemon query, and pass transfer settings into TransferPipeline.
close_reason: Hook now loads config for threshold/socket/transfer with fail-open

title: Hook: enforce protocol-safe output + streaming behavior
description:
Background
- Claude Code hook protocol expects empty stdout to allow; JSON output to deny.

Goals
- Ensure hook outputs are correct and consistent for success/failure.
- Include clear deny reasons when remote compilation is used.
- Avoid noisy output to stdout in allow path.

Considerations
- Streaming should go to stderr; stdout reserved for hook response.
design: Treat stdout as control channel; stderr as data channel.
acceptance_criteria:
- Allow path produces empty stdout.
- Deny path includes JSON with clear reason.
- Streaming output uses stderr only.
notes: Verified in rch/src/hook.rs: allow path emits no stdout; deny path emits JSON only. execute_remote_compilation streams both stdout/stderr via eprintln (stderr), keeping stdout reserved for hook protocol.
close_reason: Hook output/streaming behavior already protocol-safe

Logging

design: Prefer deterministic mocks; avoid real network/rsync in unit tests.
acceptance_criteria:

- Integration tests validate daemon request parsing and response handling.
- Mocked pipeline verifies proper sequencing and fail-open behavior.
notes: Align test logs with e2e script logs to simplify troubleshooting.

title: WorkerPool: Correctness & Health
description:
Purpose
- Ensure WorkerPool accounting and status mutation are correct and thread-safe.
- Health monitor should allow unreachable workers to recover.

Key Risks
- Incorrect availability leading to overcommit or starvation.
- Workers stuck in unreachable state forever.
design: Use interior mutability (RwLock or atomics) for status; avoid blocking slow paths. Health should poll all workers to allow recovery.
acceptance_criteria:
- WorkerPool length reflects actual workers.
- Worker status can be updated safely; health monitor checks all workers.
- Tests validate status transitions and selection behavior.
notes: If fixes are already merged, ensure tests capture the regressions that prompted the fixes.
close_reason: All child tasks completed: WorkerPool length accounting (ei5.2.1), status mutation + health recovery (ei5.2.2), and selection tests (ei5.2.3). All 26 rchd tests pass.

title: WorkerPool: accurate length accounting
description:
Background
- WorkerPool must report actual worker count and be safe for concurrent access.

Goals
- Implement accurate len() using AtomicUsize or async lock-based length.
- Ensure add/remove paths keep count correct.

Considerations
- Keep read access fast (no full lock unless necessary).
design: If using atomic counters, ensure increments happen only when inserting a new worker.
acceptance_criteria:
- len() reflects real worker count.
- Tests demonstrate len() increments on add and remains stable.
notes: Verified in rchd/src/workers.rs: WorkerPool tracks worker_count via AtomicUsize, incremented on insert; len() reads worker_count; all_workers() exists for health monitoring.
close_reason: Worker count tracking implemented in rchd/src/workers.rs

title: WorkerPool: status mutation + health recovery
description:
Background
- Worker status must be mutable and visible to selection and health systems.

Goals
- Add interior mutability for status (RwLock or atomics).
- Health monitor should check all workers (not just healthy) to allow recovery.
- Ensure selection only uses healthy workers.
design: Avoid holding locks during long operations; update status after health check completes.
acceptance_criteria:
- set_status updates state safely and is reflected in selection.
- Health monitor evaluates all workers each interval.
- Tests cover transition to degraded/unreachable and recovery.
notes: Verified in rchd/src/workers.rs: WorkerState status uses RwLock with async getters/setters; WorkerPool set_status updates state. rchd/src/health.rs checks all_workers each interval, enabling recovery from unreachable.
close_reason: Status mutability + health recovery implemented

title: Worker selection: healthy-only + slot-aware tests
description:
Background
- Selection must respect worker health and slot availability.

Goals
- Ensure selection filters unhealthy workers.
- Validate reservation and release paths via tests.
design: Keep selection deterministic; prefer explicit weights and clear logs.
acceptance_criteria:
- Selection ignores degraded/unreachable workers.
- Unit tests validate scoring and filtering behavior.
notes: If selection already correct, add tests to lock it in.
close_reason: Selection tests exist and pass: test_select_worker_ignores_unhealthy verifies unhealthy workers are filtered, test_select_worker_respects_slot_availability verifies slot availability is respected. All 3 selection tests pass.

- Provide clear human-readable output with optional JSON support.

Key Risks
- Incomplete or misleading output makes debugging difficult.
- Commands that mutate system state must be explicit and safe.
design: Keep CLI thin: prefer calling daemon APIs or shared config helpers. Avoid long-running operations in the hook process. Ensure consistent output formatting across commands.
acceptance_criteria:
- All CLI subcommands in rch/main.rs are implemented (no TODO stubs remain).
- Each command has clear output and error handling.
- Tests exist for key command paths and input validation.
notes: There is an in-progress issue for CLI handlers; reparent it under this epic and expand scope/acceptance to cover all subcommands.
